label.INDMHEALTH: Percentage with GHQ12 scores ≥4 (signifying possible mental health problem)

result.label: Indicator - Mental health
note:
[b]Mental health[/b]

[b]How do we measure this?[/b]
Percentage aged 16+ with general health questionnaire-12 (GHQ12) scores greater than or equal to 4 (signifying possible mental health problem). For this indicator a lower figure is better.

[b]Source[/b]
Health Survey Northern Ireland, Department of Health
[url=https://www.health-ni.gov.uk/topics/doh-statistics-and-research/health-survey-northern-ireland]https://www.health-ni.gov.uk/topics/doh-statistics-and-research/health-survey-northern-ireland[/url] 

[b]Impact of Covid-19[/b]
Due to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, data collection for the 2020/21, 2021/22 and 2022/23 Health Survey Northern Ireland moved from face-to-face interviewing (with GHQ12 administered as a self-completion module) to telephone mode. In 2023/24, face-to-face interviewing was reinstated alongside telephone interviewing in June 2023, thus the survey adopted a mixed mode methodology. Caution should be taken in reaching any conclusions based on 2020/21, 2021/22, 2022/23 and 2023/24 data and comparisons with previous years as the findings may not be directly comparable. Further details on these changes can be found at the start of the Health Survey Northern Ireland 2023/24 report, entitled ‘Health Survey Northern Ireland 2023/24 - Things users need to know'.

[b]Further information[/b]
1. The GHQ12 information is collected as part of the [url=https://www.health-ni.gov.uk/topics/doh-statistics-and-research/health-survey-northern-ireland]Health Survey Northern Ireland[/url]. The statistics presented here relate to the proportion of adult respondents that scored four or more on the GHQ12 scale and are referred to as having a ‘high GHQ12 score’. A high score signifies a possible mental health problem.
2. In 2018/19, as part of an ongoing methodological review, a revised weighting methodology has been adopted. For comparison purposes, the previous years have been updated to reflect the revised methodology.
3. Data is not available for 2012/13 as the questions were not included in the survey. 
4. Prior to the commencement of the Health Survey NI in 2010/11, data were collected in the NI Continuous Household Survey (2009/10) and the NI Health and Wellbeing Survey (2005/06).
5. Respondents are aged 16+.
6. As the 2020/21, 2021/22 and 2022/23 health surveys were carried out in telephone mode and the 2023/24 health survey was in mixed mode, results may not be fully comparable with those collected as self-completion during a household interview.
7. For more information on this data please contact the data provider Public Health Information & Research Branch, Information Analysis Directorate, DOH, email: [url=mailto:phirb@health-ni.gov.uk]phirb@health-ni.gov.uk[/url] or further information on the Health Survey is available online at [url=https://www.health-ni.gov.uk/topics/doh-statistics-and-research/health-survey-northern-ireland]https://www.health-ni.gov.uk/topics/doh-statistics-and-research/health-survey-northern-ireland[/url]

[b]Sex[/b]
8. In 2023/24, there was no significant difference between males and females with respect of having a high GHQ12 score. The proportion of males and females with a high GHQ12 score is unchanged from the comparison year of 2019/20. Considering the longer term trend, the proportion of both males and females scoring highly remains similar to their respective levels in 2010/11.
Further information on how to interpret the survey estimates and detail on the sample size and confidence intervals is available at: [url=https://view.officeapps.live.com/op/view.aspx?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.health-ni.gov.uk%2Fsites%2Fdefault%2Ffiles%2F2025-05%2Fghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx&wdOrigin=BROWSELINK]ghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx[/url] 

[b]Age[/b]
9. In 2023/24, respondents in the 75+ age group were the least likely to have a high GHQ12 score. This was also the only age group that saw a decrease from the comparison year of 2019/20. Considering the longer term trend, estimates across the age groups have remained at broadly similar levels to 2010/11. 
Further information on how to interpret the survey estimates and detail on the sample size and confidence intervals is available at: [url=https://view.officeapps.live.com/op/view.aspx?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.health-ni.gov.uk%2Fsites%2Fdefault%2Ffiles%2F2025-05%2Fghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx&wdOrigin=BROWSELINK]ghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx[/url]

[b]Marital status[/b]
10. In 2023/24, respondents who were married or in a civil partnership were less likely to have a high GHQ12 score than those that were single, separated, divorced or widowed. In comparison with 2019/20, all categories remained at similar levels. Considering the longer term trend, in comparison with 2010/11, there was a decrease for those who were married or in a civil partnership and those who were divorced. Further information on how to interpret the survey estimates and detail on the sample size and confidence intervals is available at: [url=https://view.officeapps.live.com/op/view.aspx?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.health-ni.gov.uk%2Fsites%2Fdefault%2Ffiles%2F2025-05%2Fghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx&wdOrigin=BROWSELINK]ghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx[/url]
11. The marital status categories were amended from 2013/14 onwards to capture more detail on civil partnerships. It is not considered that this will have had an impact on the data.
12. Some estimates have been suppressed due to small sample sizes (less than 100 respondents).

[b]Religion[/b]
13. In 2023/24, there was no difference between Catholics and Protestants in terms of scoring highly on the GHQ12. In comparison with 2019/20, there was a decrease noted for those who were Protestant, with the other categories remaining at similar levels. Considering the longer term trend, estimates across the categories remain at similar levels to 2010/11. 
Further information on how to interpret the survey estimates and detail on the sample size and confidence intervals is available at: [url=https://view.officeapps.live.com/op/view.aspx?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.health-ni.gov.uk%2Fsites%2Fdefault%2Ffiles%2F2025-05%2Fghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx&wdOrigin=BROWSELINK]ghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx[/url]
14. 'Other' includes those with any other religion other than Catholic and Protestant, those with no religion and those who did not state a religion.

[b]Deprivation[/b]
15. A consistent gap remains between the most and least deprived areas, with respondents in the most deprived areas (27%) continuing to be more likely to have a high GHQ12 score than those in the least deprived areas (15%). In comparison with 2019/20, all quintiles remained at similar levels. Considering the longer term trend, estimates remain at similar levels to 2010/11. 
Further information on how to interpret the survey estimates and detail on the sample size and confidence intervals is available at: [url=https://view.officeapps.live.com/op/view.aspx?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.health-ni.gov.uk%2Fsites%2Fdefault%2Ffiles%2F2025-05%2Fghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx&wdOrigin=BROWSELINK]ghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx[/url]
16. All figures up to and including 2017/18 are defined according to the 2010 NIMDM; figures from 2018/19 onwards are based on the 2017 NIMDM. More information on the NI Multiple Deprivation Measures can be found here: [url=https://www.nisra.gov.uk/statistics/deprivation]https://www.nisra.gov.uk/statistics/deprivation[/url]

[b]Urban Rural[/b]
17. In 2023/24, respondents in urban areas (22%) were more likely than those in rural areas (16%) to have a high GHQ12 score. In comparison with 2019/20, the proportion scoring highly in all areas remained at similar levels. Considering the longer term trend, estimates across the categories remain at similar levels to 2010/11.
Further information on how to interpret the survey estimates and detail on the sample size and confidence intervals is available at: [url=https://view.officeapps.live.com/op/view.aspx?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.health-ni.gov.uk%2Fsites%2Fdefault%2Ffiles%2F2025-05%2Fghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx&wdOrigin=BROWSELINK]ghq12-pfg-tables-hsni.xlsx[/url]
18. Figures up to and including 2015 are defined according 2005 urban rural classification; figures from 2016 onwards are based on the 2015 urban rural classification: [url=https://www.nisra.gov.uk/support/geography/urban-rural-classification]https://www.nisra.gov.uk/support/geography/urban-rural-classification[/url]
